channel.title: books on Tushar Chandra
channel.description: Recent content in books on Tushar Chandra

item.title: Something that made me a better programmer
item.description: Something that has made me a better programmer is thinking through my code step-by-step before I run it. Stupid, right? It kind of seems that way in hindsight, but writing about it makes me feel better.

item.title: What I read this week (May 24 - May 30)
item.description: This week, I read a lot of advice: on writing, on grad school, and more. Most of this was written while waiting for a particularly painful MCMC model to sample.

item.title: PMD password tool: should I do this?
item.description: This is a long one; it’s not a paper summary, it’s not technical, and it’s far more personal than what I usually post here. In this post, I discuss whether or not the password tool should even exist by telling a story about a community from 14 years ago.

item.title: Bookmarklet for SudokuExchange
item.description: I’ve been playing a lot of Sudoku while at home, and today I made a quick tool to make it easier for myself: a bookmarklet to open NY Times Sudoku puzzles on SudokuExchange.com.

item.title: What I read this week (May 17 - May 23)
item.description: I spent most of my free time this week working on my island in Animal Crossing and the rescue project; but this week’s articles include an article from FB Engineering about rebuilding their main site, an article about distractions, and a host of shorter articles.

item.title: PMD password tool: making it all work
item.description: After clearing up unexpected challenges and removing roadblocks, all that was left was to build. A full evening of coding later, the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon rescue tool works, which is huge! This post reflects on the last few steps of the process.

item.title: [Paper] Taking Data Out of Context to Hyper-Personalize Ads: Crowdworkers' Privacy Perceptions and Decisions to Disclose Private Information
Hacking together Python and JavaScript
item.description: Alternative title: “Python in the browser console tells us that science has indeed come too far.” The fourth post in this series dives into how Pyodide enabled me to hook up Python and JavaScript—sometimes in less-than-clean ways.

item.title: What I read this week (May 10 - May 16)
item.description: I took last week off as I focused on full papers from CHI, but this week’s edition of Pointer had several articles that caught my eye.

item.title: [Paper] How Visualizing Inferential Uncertainty Can Mislead Readers About Treatment Effects in Scientific Results
item.description: When visualizing the uncertainty around treatment effects, one can choose (among others) to visualize the standard error (uncertainty in the mean) or the standard deviations (uncertainty in the observations). Modulo sample size, the two contain the same information, but this paper demonstrates how people regularly associate the former with larger effects than the latter.

item.title: [Paper] Modeling Organizational Culture with Workplace Experiences Shared on Glassdoor
item.description: Glassdoor is a valuable source of data on what life is like at different companies, and in particular the organizational culture there. To what extent can organizational culture be modeled using word embeddings? Is it useful for predicting job performance. This paper, from the De Choudhury lab at Georgia Tech, investigates.

item.title: A data scientist builds a web app
item.description: Continuing my series on buliding a tool for Pokemon Mystery Dungeon, this post describes my experiences trying, failing, and trying again to build a web app.

item.title: [Paper] What's Wrong with Computational Notebooks? Pain Points, Needs, and Design Opportunities
item.description: Computational notebooks are one of the most common tools in the data science world, but they are not without their limitations. This paper studies pain points and design opportunities for notebooks as used by professional data scientists.

item.title: [Paper] Understanding and Visualizing Data Iteration in Machine Learning
item.description: Machine learning is as much—if not more—about the data as it is the models. This paper explores data iteration, in contrast to model iteration, and studies ways that ML practitioners manage changing data.

item.title: [Paper] How to Trick AI: Users' Strategies for Protecting Themselves from Automatic Personality Assessment
item.description: Suppose you were talking to a chatbot who was trying to infer your personality. To what extent would you be able to fake a personality and trick the bot? That’s the central question in this paper by VÃ¶lkel et al., which gets at deep questions about the transparency of and ethics behind computing systems.

item.title: [Paper] Emergent Self-Regulation Practices in Technology and Social Media Use of Individuals Living with Depression
item.description: How do people with depression use technology at a personal level? The answer “they all use it differently” may or may not be surprising, depending on your perspective, but in my experience this is often assumed to be the case. Eschler et al. take on this question by interviewing people about the roles technology plays in their lives and opportunities to use it in a healthy way.

item.title: [Paper] Re-Shape: A Method to Teach Data Ethics for Data Science Education
item.description: Imagine that a week of your personal location data were made public. What would strangers be able to learn about you? The authors use this question to motivate Re-Shape, a method for teaching students about the ethics of data collection and use, building on the feminist idea of “cultivating care.”

item.title: [Paper] Celebrating Everyday Success: Improving Engagement and Motivation using a System for Recording Daily Highlights
item.description: Recognizing your own successes is important for cultivating a positive outlook and sense of purpose. Modern work environments often do not offer this, with the idea of there always being more to do standing in the way of reflection that celebrates progress. Highlight Matome is a personal online tool for workers to quickly record short, daily highlights with the goal of improving their inner work life.

item.title: What I read this week (April 26 - May 2)
item.description: This week, I’ve focused mostly on articles from CHI, but I did read a few shorter things in my spare time.

item.title: [Paper] In-game and Out-of-game Social Anxiety Influences Player Motivations, Activities, and Experiences in MMORPGs
item.description: How are MMORPGs perceived by people with social anxiety? What do they find enjoyable about MMORPGS? How does real-world anxiety translate to social experiences in a video game setting? This CHI 2020 paper by Dechant et al. studies these and other questions about the interactions between social anxiety and video games.
